My Why

Memory is the most idiosyncratic, humanistic aspect in us. It is the story that we keep telling ourselves about who we are, why we do things the way we do, and how it shapes the person we’re becoming. It’s hauntingly beautiful and sometimes painfully poetic, but most importantly, it’s innately prevalent in our everyday life. To me, memory is what gives life meaning. How can something so abstract, so difficult to conceptualize, be so ingrained in our identity? Clearly, we don’t know much about ourselves as we let on.


My purpose in life is to understand what makes us truly us. Not just through intellectual frameworks, but also through humanistic lenses because both are connected and of the same system.


As Jill Bolte Taylor said, "Most of us think of ourselves as thinking creatures that feel, but we are actually feeling creatures that think."
